Ye valleys to which I complain,</br>Now trac'd with the tear-streaming eye,</br>I know that my sorrows are vain,</br>Yet love to indulge the fond sigh!
To muse on the days that are flown,</br>To think, dearest LUCY on thee!</br>My heart must be cold as thy own,</br>Ere lost the remembrance can be.
When summer in beauty array'd,</br>Shone here with a splendor refin'd,</br>In thee all its charms were display'd,</br>In thee all its beauties conjoin'd.
Thy smile, to its lustre serene,</br>The glories of Eden restor'd:</br>Whose death gave a damp to the scene,</br>Whose death will be ever deplor'd!
Who rose, the sweet Flow'r of Delight!</br>Of Nature's perfection, in bloom:</br>Now lost in the confines of Night,</br>Conceal'd in the shade of the Tomb!
In whom love and friendship I found;</br>Heart-piercing reflection to me!</br>O LUCY — each object around,</br>Reminds thy LORENZO of thee.
The winter now frowns on the year,</br>And loudly the hurricanes howl,</br>How lov'd — for a semblance they bear,</br>To the tempests that rage in my soul!
All Nature is sadden'd to woe,</br>The songsters no longer are gay;</br>Dejected they sit on each bough,</br>And mourn o'er the season's decay:
But Nature again shall rejoice;</br>And Spring all her beauties restore;</br>The songsters again raise their voice</br>In melody sweet as before!
The scene that so gloomy appears,</br>Again shall its brightness resume:</br>Yet I shall explore it in tears,</br>Nor raise my sad hopes from the tomb!
The Tomb, over which I reline,</br>That cruelly keeps thee from view,</br>Dear LUCY, may shortly be mine!</br>That prospect is all I pursue.
The sports of the village I wave;</br>No longer endearing to me:</br>O LUCY — my soul's in the grave,</br>My wishes all centre in thee!</br>
